newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysian mines chamber says no tin quota sales.
newsitem.headline: Malaysian mines chamber says no tin quota sales.

text.p: The Malaysian Chamber of Mines (MCM) said on Wednesday the sharp fall in tin prices on the London Metal Exchange (LME) this week was not due to attempts by Malaysia to exhaust any export quota for tin.
"There is no quota for tin exports in Malaysia," Muhammad Nor Muhammad, executive director of the MCM, said. "If the market is referring to the ATPC export quota, then that no longer exists."
Tin has hit consecutive 18-month lows on the LME this week and on Tuesday dipped to a nadir of $5,760 a tonne before ending at $5,770, down $70.
A London industry analyst said the fall was partly due to selling by China and Malaysia, which had sought to take advantage of their domestic tin export quotas before year-end.
Muhammad Nor said the only export quota in the tin industry had been that of the Association Tin Producing Countries (ATPC) and that was abolished in June.
Malaysian traders said on Tuesday they were not aware of any selling from Malaysia on the London market.
The Kuala Lumpur Tin Market fell 19 Malaysian cents to 14.72 ringgit ($5.84) a kg on Monday and ended unchanged on Tuesday.
